description: In this survey we explore the relationships between technical knowledge and war in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. We attend particularly to the centrality of bodily injury in the history of war. Topics include changing interpretations of the machine gun as inhumane or acceptable; the cult of the battleship; banned weaponry; submarines and masculinity; industrialized war and total war; trench warfare and mental breakdown; the atomic bomb and Cold War; chemical warfare in Viet Nam; and "television war" in the 1990s.
name: SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY & WAR

values.comments: Although though some of the assigned readings were a bit “long and dry,” students agreed that overall, this was a very stimulating and valuable course. Reviewers praised Professor Lindee for not only conveying the material in lecture extremely well but also for showing great interest and concern in her students’ understanding of the material.
